where $\beta=dd^c |z|^2$ and $SH_m(\Omega)$ is the set of   $m$-subharmonic functions in $\Omega$.  
In the case $m=n$ then the equation \eqref{eq1.1} is the  Dirichlet problem for the complex Monge-Amp\`ere operator. Moreover, if $f=0$ then this  complex Monge-Amp\`ere equation becomes  the Bremermann-Dirichlet problem for plurisubharmonic functions.


Bedford and  Taylor \cite{BT76} studied the   Dirichlet problem for a complex Monge-Amp\`ere operator. They showed that, if $\Omega$ is a strictly pseudoconvex domain and $f\in \mathcal C(\overline{\Omega})$ then there exists a continuous solution $u$ on $\overline{\Omega}$.
Ko{\l}odziej \cite{Ko95} proved that the complex Monge-Amp\`ere equation has a continuous solution in strictly pseudoconvex domain.  Later on,
Guedj, Ko\l odziej and Zeriahi \cite{GKZ08} showed that this solution is H\"older continuous. Recently,  Charabati \cite{Ch15}  studied the H\"{o}lder regularity for solutions to complex Monge-Amp\`{e}re equations in bounded strongly hyperconvex Lipschitz domain. 

 
The complex Hessian equation \eqref{eq1.1} was first studied by  Li \cite{Li04}. He  proved that, if    $\Omega$ is smoothly bounded $(m-1)$-pseudoconvex domain and $\phi,f$ are smooth functions on $\overline{\Omega}$, then  there exists a  smooth solution to \eqref{eq1.1}.
Next, B\l ocki \cite{Bl05}  studied  some elements of potential theory for $m$-subharmonic functions and the complex Hessian operator. Later on, 
Dinew and Ko\l odziej \cite{DK14} proved that there exists a unique continuous solution to \eqref{eq1.1} in smoothly bounded $(m-1)$-pseudoconvex domain. 
Recently, Cuong \cite{Cuong}   proved the H\"older continuity of solutions to \eqref{eq1.1} in  strongly bounded, strongly $m$-pseudoconvex domain.  


There is a natural question that is whether there exists a  continuous solution to \eqref{eq1.1} in unbounded domains. Simioniuc and  Tomassini \cite{ST08} studied the Bremermann-Dirichlet problem for   plurisubharmonic functions in  unbounded domains of $\mathbb C^n$.
They proved that, if $\Omega$ is an unbounded strongly pseudoconvex domain which verifies the condition $(L)$ and $\phi$ be non-negative continuous function, then there exists a continuous maximal  plurisubharmonic function $u$ defined in $\Omega$ such that $u|_{\partial \Omega} =\phi$. 


The aim of this paper is to provide sufficient conditions for the existence of continuous solution to \eqref{eq1.1} in unbounded domain of $\mathbb C^n$.  
Our main result is the following theorem.\\

\noindent 
{\bf Main Theorem.} {\em 
Let  $\Omega$ be an unbounded    domain in $\mathbb C^n$ such that
there exists a bounded   Lipschitz continuous  function $\rho:\overline{\Omega} \to \mathbb R$  satisfying:  

(a) $\Omega=\{\rho<0\}$ and $\partial \Omega =\{\rho=0\}$;

(b)  $\{\rho<-\varepsilon\}\Subset \Omega$ for all $\varepsilon>0$;

(c) $\rho(z) - |z|^2$ is $m$-subharmonic in $\Omega$;

(d) $\int_\Omega dd^c \rho \wedge \beta^{n-1} <+\infty$.

\noindent 
Assume that $\phi \in   \mathcal C^{1,1}(\overline{\Omega}) $ is  bounded Lipschitz continuous   function on $\overline{\Omega}$ and  $0\leq f\in L^p(\Omega)$, $p>\frac{n}{m}$ such that   $f$ is bounded  in $\Omega \backslash K$ for some $K\Subset \Omega$. Then,  there exists a continuous solution $u$ to \eqref{eq1.1}  on $\overline{\Omega}$.
Moreover, if  $f=0$ in $\Omega \backslash K$ then this solution  is  locally $\alpha$-H\"{o}lder continuous on $\overline{\Omega}$  for all

(dd^{c}u)^{m}\wedge\beta^{n-m}=f\beta^{n},\\
\lim_{z\to\xi}u(z)=\phi(\xi),\ \forall\xi\in\partial\Omega,\end{cases}" display="block"><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∩</mo><mrow><msup><mi>L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd/></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>d</mi><mi>c</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>u</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>m</mi></msup><mo>∧</mo><msup><mi>β</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>β</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd/></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mo>lim</mo><mrow><mi>z</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>ξ</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ξ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>∀</mo><mi>ξ</mi></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd/></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>

Without loss of generality we can assume that    $\Omega_j$ be smoothly bounded strongly $m$-hyperconvex domain.
